Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Communications with Energy Harvesting Nodes

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wireless networks composed of nodes that can harvest energy from the environment represent the green future of communications. Utilizing the harvested ambient energy improves the environmental impact of wireless devices in the global scale, while extending the network lifetime indefinitely and making the devices truly mobile. Energy harvesting (EH) brings new dimensions to system design in the form of randomness and intermittency of available energy, as well as additional system issues such as energy storage capacity and processing complexity. Additionally, the deployment of EH wireless networks calls for novel techniques for resource and interference management, cooperation among EH nodes, as well as cross-layer optimization of the network.

The research focuses on a new set of challenges brought about by wireless networks composed of EH nodes. The research directions are divided into four major thrusts. (1) The first challenge is to understand the fundamental limit of EH communications in the information theoretic setting, accounting for random and intermittent supply of available energy, finite battery capacity with storage and withdrawal efficiencies. The special cases for low-power and high-power regimes are of particular interest. (2) In order to make efficient use of the available resources, joint energy scheduling and spectral and/or spatial resource allocation in EH networks exploiting the inherent structure of the resource allocation problems becomes an important problem. (3) Different EH nodes in the network can share their harvested energy either through the presence of power line between them, or through wireless charging. The research studies previous thrusts with energy and data cooperation. (4) The research investigates efficient distributed cross-layer solutions to maximize the total system utility subject to data and energy queuing stability constraints.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wireless networks composed of nodes that can harvest energy from the environment represent the green future of communications. Utilizing the harvested ambient energy improves the environmental impact of wireless devices in the global scale, while extending the network lifetime indenitely and making the devices truly mobile. Energy harvesting (EH) brings new dimensions to system design in the form of randomness and intermittency of available energy, as well as additional system issues such as energy storage capacity and processing complexity. Additionally, the deployment of EH wireless networks calls for novel techniques for resource and interference management, cooperation among EH nodes, as well as cross-layer optimization of the network.

Intellectual Merit: This project tackles a set of challenges brought about by wireless networks composed of EH nodes, and made significant contributions to the following our technical areas. (1) Developed tools for analyzing the capacity of EH wireless networks and understanding the fundamental limit of EH communications.  (2) Developed resource allocation algorithms that can make efficient use of the harvested energy as well as other wireless resources. (3) Developed efficient energy and data cooperation schemes for EH networks. (4) Developed distributed cross-layer optimization strategies for EH communications to maximize the total system utility subject to data and energy queuing stability constraints.

Broader Impact: The techniques developed in this project can significantly increase the energy eciency and spectral eciency of next-generation wireless networks. Renewable energy based transmitters can be thought of as low cost devices that can be placed to improve throughput in their vicinity, andhelp decrease the load from traditional grid-powered transmitters and thus increase the overall system throughput. This will make mobile broadband more affordable and thus accessible to a broader segment of the public, in line with the goals of the National Broadband Plan. During the course of this project we have engaged Ph.D., M.S. and undergraduate students. We have actively promoted the participation of minority students and female students. We have also coordinated with an established outreach programs to engage K-12 students and traditionally under-represented groups, and inspire these students to pursue STEM education and careers.
